In Yarp binary distribution in Windows, we just copy the relocatable `**Config.cmake` (as explained by @chrisdembia ) in the installer. 

The cool thing is that if you install the library to some specific system paths (the one contained in `CMAKE_SYSTEM_PREFIX_PATH`) and the 
`**Config.cmake` are contained in the project directories with a given structure (as documented in the [
  find_package](http://www.cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/command/find_package.html) documentation) you don't need to define 
any specific environmental variable to find the installed libraries.

 Furthermore, even if you install  all the projects in a non-system location, you just to add the installation prefix  to 
the `CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH` and you will find automatically all the packages installed in that location, without
hardcoding any path in the `configure.bat` file (or just hardcoding there the `CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH`) .

The cool thing is that if you install the library to some specific system paths (the one contained in CMAKE_SYSTEM_PREFIX_PATH) and the **Config.cmake are contained in the project directories with a given structure (as documented in the find_package documentation) you don't need to define any specific environmental variable to find the installed libraries.

Furthermore, even if you install all the projects in a non-system location, you just to add the installation prefix to the CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH and you will find automatically all the packages installed in that location, without hardcoding any path in the configure.bat file (or just hardcoding there the CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH) .
